description:
Cyprinella venusta, commonly known as the blacktail shiner, is a small freshwater fish species belonging to the family Cyprinidae. It is native to the central and southeastern United States, found primarily in the Mississippi River basin and Gulf Coast region.

The blacktail shiner is a small, slender fish, typically reaching a maximum length of around 10 centimeters (4 inches). Its most distinctive feature is the dark, wedge-shaped blotch at the base of its tail fin, which gives the species its common name. The body coloration is typically olive-green or silvery-gray, with a white or yellowish belly.

Cyprinella venusta is an omnivorous species, feeding on a variety of aquatic invertebrates, algae, and plant material. It plays an important role in the ecosystem as a forage fish, providing a food source for larger predatory species.

This species prefers clear, clean, and well-oxygenated streams, rivers, and reservoirs with gravel or rocky substrates. It is generally considered a hardy and adaptable fish, able to tolerate a range of environmental conditions.

Cyprinella venusta is an ecologically important species, contributing to the overall biodiversity and functioning of the aquatic ecosystems it inhabits. It is widely distributed and considered a common and stable species throughout much of its native range.
